awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative: PHY-Informed Networking (PHY-IN): Rethinking Wireless Protocol Design with the Knowledge of PHY
awd_abstract_narration:
Traditionally, there has been an isolation of responsibilities of
physical layer (PHY) and higher layers of the network stack leading to
severe inefficiencies in bandwidth-limited wireless
networks. Remedying these inefficiencies requires rethinking and
redesigning wireless protocols such that higher layers and PHY work in
synergy. This project explores three schemes under the PHY-Informed
Networking (PHY-IN) framework. 1) Carrier Sense Multiple Access with
Collision Notification (CSMA/CN) mechanism detects and aborts
collisions, breaking away from the existing collision avoidance
(CSMA/CA) based schemes such as 802.11. 2) Constellation BAsed Rate
(CBAR) adaptation scheme jumps to the best feasible rate suitable for
a varying channel. 3) Remap scheme permutes bit-to-subcarrier
assignment for a retransmission to improve the chances of its success.
The PHY-IN framework has the potential to impact the landscape of
future wireless networking protocols. Apart from mentoring both
undergraduate and graduate students into independent researchers, this
project, involving an EPSCoR university and a research lab, will also
help broaden the participation and industry collaboration.

por.por_cntn:
This project has shown that there is a substantial scope for improving the performance of wireless networks by rethinking and redesigning wireless protocols such that higher layer protocols and physical layer work in synergy. An outcome of this project is a virtual countdown scheme in the frequency domain for resolving contention among multiple transmitters in a wireless network.  This approach is shown to be a much more efficient alternative to the well established time-domain backoff in today's WiFi networks.

Another outcome of this project is the demonstration of the feasibility of detecting and aborting colliding transmissions in wireless networks, thus breaking away from long pursued approach of collision avoidance. The key idea behind this scheme, called Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Notification, is the usage of signal correlation instead of conventional decoding to detect collision notification. This makes the detection more robust to interference and thus reduces the signal-to-interference threshold required for accurate detection. This idea has been adopted in many follow up works by other wireless networking researchers for conveying control information.

The research work from this project has resulted in three publications in well known journals, IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking, IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, and IEEE Communication Letters, and three presentations at highly visible workshops and conferences, ACM HotNets, HotWireless, and MobiCom. The results from this project are also disseminated to the broader community through invited lectures at universities and research institutes in USA and India.

This project also contributed in the graduation of four, one PhD, two Masters, and two Bachelors, students with attractive career options, having gained a deeper understanding of wireless protocols and programming experience with Software Radio platforms such as USRP and GnuRadio. Three of them joined industry and two others continuing their research in academia. The PhD student received Outstanding Research Assistant award from our department. One of the Masters students graduated with university-wide Outstanding Thesis Award. An undergraduate student involved in this project received several university-wide honors at USC in addition to the Goldwater Scholarship and the NSF Graduate Fellowship.
